    GWAS

    GWAS.Rmd

    GWAS

    GWAS is short for genome-wide association study, which is a method used to identify gene variations that are statistically associated with a risk for a disease. Once a large enough dataset has been collected the approach is to look for genomic variants that occur more frequently in those with a specific disease compared to those without the disease. GWAS in practices makes a simple linear regression on each genomic variant (values at a particular SNP) and the case-control status for each individual. We note that other implementations of GWAS exist, but that this is the one used in RyouSick. Among other statistics it gives us a p-value indicating the statistical significance of our observations. Choosing a threshold p-value we can then determine whether a SNP might be causal or not based on if its p-value higher or lower than our chosen threshold.

    when performing GWAS using the RyouSick package’s GWAS() function on a large population of 100.000 individuals on 100.000 SNPs we receive the following statistics given that we choose around 10% of the 100.000 SNPS to be causal:

    We note that to determine whether a SNP is causal or not we check to see if the p-value is lower or higher than the Bonferroni corrected p-value of \(5\cdot10^{-7}\), since we perform 100.000 tests/regressions.

    The results can also be visualized using a Manhattan plot that can be produced using the function Manhattan_plot() where SNPs over the dotted line represents SNPs that are counted as causal.

    This gives us an indication of where in the sequence the causal SNPs appear. A comparison between the results of the different association studies can be seen in the LTFH article vignette("LTFH").

    Developed by Nicklas Stanislaus, Markus Nielsen, Christian Mains.
